title: Synthetic Recap
body:
CHARLOTTE, N.C. – On a night where offense was a premium and points came at a desperate cost, Glen Rice ascended to a singular plane of greatness. The Charlotte Hornets star delivered a performance for the ages, pouring in a staggering 41 points to single-handedly will his team to a grinding 82-76 victory over the Miami Heat in 1997.

In a defensive battle that saw both teams struggle to find a rhythm, Rice was the exception. While teammates and opponents alike faltered, the Hornets’ forward was a picture of relentless efficiency. His 41-point explosion, an outlier in a game where no other player even cracked 15 points, was the entire story. The Hornets’ offense, outside of their superstar, managed a meager 41 points combined.

The Miami Heat, led by Alonzo Mourning’s 14 points, had no answer. Every time Charlotte needed a bucket to stem a Miami run or seize momentum, the ball found Rice. He scored from every conceivable angle, a one-man offensive system operating against a wall of defenders who knew what was coming but were powerless to stop it.

Ultimately, this was not merely a win for the Hornets; it was a coronation. In a game destined to be forgotten for its aesthetic, Glen Rice ensured it would be remembered for one breathtaking, historic reason: his name in the scoring column, a beacon of individual brilliance on a night of collective struggle.
